content: The Act titled "Visa Efficiency and E-Verify Extension Act of 2008" aims to recapture immigrant visas lost due to bureaucratic delays. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust the worldwide level of employment-based immigrants for each fiscal year, including unused visa numbers from the previous year. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust the worldwide level of employment-based immigrants for each fiscal year, including unused visa numbers from fiscal years 1992 through 2007. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants for each fiscal year, with specific calculations outlined in the amendment. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants for each fiscal year. The number computed under this paragraph is the number of certain aliens not subject to direct numerical limitations, with a minimum threshold set at 226,000. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrant visas for each fiscal year. The number computed under this paragraph is the difference between the sum of family-sponsored immigrant visas established for fiscal years 1992 through 2007 and the number of visas actually issued during those years. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to adjust family-sponsored immigrant visas for fiscal years 1992 through 2007. The amendments will take effect 60 days after the enactment of this Act. The Conrad State 30 Program is extended until June 1, 2013, and the Special Immigrant Nonminister Religious Worker Program is addressed. SEC. 4. Special Immigrant Nonminister Religious Worker Program regulations to reduce fraud and extend deadline to October 1, 2011. Inspector General to report on effectiveness by September 30, 2010. SEC. 5. Extension of the Basic Pilot Program to a 16-year period. SEC. 6. Protection of Social Security Administration programs. Effective for fiscal years starting on or after October 1, 2008, the Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Homeland Security will have an agreement to provide funding for the Commissioner's responsibilities under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. This includes acquiring and maintaining necessary technological equipment and systems, as well as addressing individuals contesting certain issues. The agreement between the Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Homeland Security includes funding for the Commissioner's responsibilities under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. This involves addressing individuals contesting tentative nonconfirmations, providing funds quarterly based on an estimating methodology, and requiring an annual accounting of actual costs incurred. The agreement between the Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Homeland Security for funding under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 will be deemed in effect on an interim basis if no agreement is reached by October 1 of the fiscal year. The interim agreement will be adjusted for inflation and changes in the volume of requests under the basic pilot confirmation system. The Commissioner and the Secretary must notify relevant committees if an agreement is not reached by October 1 for funding under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. Updates on negotiations must be provided every 90 days until an agreement is reached. GAO will conduct a study on the Basic Pilot Confirmation System. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on erroneous tentative nonconfirmations under the basic pilot confirmation system, analyzing causes, processes for remedy, and effects on individuals, employers, and Federal agencies. The Comptroller General will report the study results on erroneous tentative nonconfirmations to relevant House and Senate committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8. GAO STUDY OF EFFECTS OF BASIC PILOT PROGRAM ON SMALL ENTITIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to the Committees on the Judiciary of the United States House of Representatives and the Senate within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. The report will analyze the effects of the basic pilot program on small entities, detailing compliance costs, number of enrolled entities, and projected requirements. The report will analyze the compliance requirements, factors impacting enrollment, and steps taken to minimize economic impact on small entities participating in the program. It will also cover direct and indirect effects separately, with specific details on small businesses with fewer than 50 employees. The report will analyze compliance requirements, factors impacting enrollment, and steps to minimize economic impact on small entities with fewer than 50 employees in States mandating the basic pilot program.
